Events.RelatedDescription: Commented on issue "RequireLicenseAcceptance is sometimes incorrect in registration" (#4570) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
@scottbommarito ,looks like a monitoring issue.
In the DB RequireLicenseAcceptance=false, which is consistent with the catalog and registration: 
https://api.nuget.org/v3/registration3/autocad.objectarx.2013/index.json
https://api.nuget.org/v3/catalog0/data/2017.08.16.23.59.56/autocad.objectarx.2013.1.0.0.json

The package was edited on August 16th (which is the date you created this issue), so might be related.

Events.RelatedBody: We can leave it like this for now, and flip the condition if we ever introduce a status that's shouldn't block upload

Events.RelatedDescription: Commented on pull request "Use package status instead of deleted bit" (#4665) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: I chose `p.PackageStatusKey != PackageStatus.Deleted` here instead of `p.PackageStatusKey == PackageStatus.Available` because letting ID/title validation include other package statuses seems okay. If a package is in `Validating` state, it should definitely be included here.

Events.RelatedDescription: Commented on issue "Change username" (#4673) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi @didrikjonaker ,  
We do not support changing usernames directly. However, you can use a workaround:
1. Create a new account with your new username. If you want to reuse your current email address, I suggest you change the email address of your current NuGet.org account to another email address before creating a new account. 
2. Assign packages to the new account: from your package's page, you can "Manage Owners" and add the new account as a package owner. Once confirmed, remove the old account name as a package owner.
How do I change my user name on nuget profile?

Events.RelatedDescription: Commented on issue "[Bug] - Sdk attribute and vstemplate nuget wizard interop" (#4943) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I'm also seeing this issue on Visual Studio 15.3.4.

As shown in the first screenshot the error is _"The operation failed as details for the project \<ProjectName\> could not be loaded."_

The project is working when the template uses the old csproj format but failing as above with the new "sdk" csproj format.

- [x] https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/5444 Cross Client no-op for legacy package reference
- [x] https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/5716 GetRestoreDotnetCliToolsTask fails when missing version metadata
- [x] https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/5419 Legacy package reference does not no-op after building on package install.
- [x] https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/5778 E2E tests have incompatible templates for LSL tests

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Legacy package reference does not no-op after building on package install." (#5419) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "Cross-Client no-op for legacy package reference" (#5444) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
The secondary target of this feature is to unify the restore behavior among all our clients. 
One can restore with NuGet.exe, open VS, and then auto-restore no-ops. When that, the user can build use msbuild /t:restore and that would no-op as well. 

At this point that's not the case. 
The dg spec generated for msbuild/nuget.exe/dotnet.exe case is not the same as the one generated by VS. Some of those inconsistencies have been resolved, while others haven't. 

Here's a table of the presumed behavior (meaning, as far as we know, there might be some crazy scenarios in which this breaks, and when encountered, we'll want to fix them. 

| Project Model | NuGet.Exe & VS Client | NuGet.exe & dotnet.exe | NuGet.exe & MsBuild | VS Client & dotnet.exe | VS Client & MsBuild | MsBuild & dotnet.exe |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| .NET Core - SDK based projects | <sub>Consistent</sub> | <sub>Consistent.</sub> | <sub>Consistent.</sub> | <sub>Consistent.</sub> | <sub>Consistent.</sub> | <sub>Consistent.</sub> |
| Legacy Package Reference projects| <sub>Inconsistent.</sub>| <sub>Consistent.</sub> | <sub>Consistent.</sub> | <sub>Inconsistent.</sub> | <sub>Consistent.</sub> | <sub>Inconsistent.</sub> |
| Project.Json  | <sub>Inconsistent</sub> | <sub>Consistent.</sub> | <sub>Consistent.</sub> | <sub>Inconsistent.</sub> | <sub>Inconsistent.</sub> | <sub>Consistent.</sub> |

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: Allow packages to have satellite nuspec files for different locales" (#5885) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
stems from an internal issue: 454720

Currently there is no way for package authors to provide sattelite nuspec files.

Adding this feature would allow the PM UI to display localized package descriptions, which would be helpful for non-english users.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "There is no warning when using code from indirect package reference leading to potential runtime errors" (#5715) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
There is a fairly simple case in the new PackageReference world where a runtime error can occur where it could be prevented or flagged by maybe msbuild or the compiler. It comes about because we can happily call code that is in indirectly referenced packages, not just in the top level ones.

Detailed Scenario:

3 packages: PackA, PackB and PackC (all .net standard 1.4 in my case)

One app: App1 (.net framework or .net core)

1. PackA has no dependencies

2. PackB v1.0.0 has PackageReference to PackA (doesn't matter if it actually uses it or not)

3. PackC has PackageReference to PackB (v1.0.0) but directly uses method in PackA. It is unfortunately able to do this even though it doesn't explicitly list PackA as a PackageReference. Maybe the developer uses PackB so adds that and doesn't realise they were then also using PackA (easy to do with internal company packages as you tend to remember what functions exist more than what packages they live in).

4. App1 has PackageReference to PackC and PackB (v.1.0.0).

5. Everything works nicely but then...

6. PackB v1.0.1 is released, which removes the PackageReference to PackA.

7. App1 updates PackB to v1.0.1

8. App1 compiles but when it calls PackC which then tries to call PackA, it fails with FileNotFoundException because PackA is not known to be a dependency so does not get included in the build. 

My thought is that the ideal way to fix this would be a compiler error or warning at step 3, but open to other suggestions. This could be done through some secondary type of DLL reference that couldn't be directly bound to.

I'm concerned we will hit this a lot with our internal packages as we try to remove indirect packages when we convert from packages.config to PackageReference.

VS version (if appropriate): 2017.2 and 2017.3

Sample project attached in broken state having updated PackB to 1.0.1

[IndirectPackageReferences.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/1206163/IndirectPackageReferences.zip)

Events.RelatedDescription: Commented on issue "There is no warning when using code from indirect package reference leading to potential runtime errors" (#5715) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: Moved to https://github.com/dotnet/roslyn/issues/22095 as I think it should be fixed at compiler level

Events.RelatedDescription: Commented on issue "automatic nuget restore in visual studio for custom project system" (#5868) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
@zivkan it may be easier to use a bare bones Project System like the examples in VSProjectSystem because the .NET project system probably does a lot more that what you need. However if you want to get nominate/restore working, you can do so on an instance of VS that has the .NET project system installed by leveraging **Capabilities** to MEF import our assemblies. 

I've been experimenting with this and got restore and dependencies tree working on a barebones CPS project. Review [this diff to NuGetizer](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Build.Packaging/compare/dev...natidea:packageRef) for examples of the changes needed. To summarize the steps you will need to replicate this:

1. Add the _PackageReferences_ and _DependenciesTree_ capabilities to your project, and copy [these rules from .NET Project system](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Build.Packaging/compare/dev...natidea:packageRef#diff-e418ff90840f18d695d653aa56e9ca98)
2. You will also need a modified version of .NET Project System that leverages this capability. You could try building this branch: [packRefCapability](https://github.com/natidea/roslyn-project-system/tree/packRefCapability), and unzipping the ProjectSystem.vsix to `%VSINSTALLDIR%Common7\IDE\Extensions\<extension>`
3. Projects created with your project-system will also need to reference the Sdk (or a subset of it). I do this [here](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Build.Packaging/compare/dev...natidea:packageRef#diff-2b7d1b66f423104d6e9a34343698307bL2), except using a stripped down version of the Sdk that only references the file [Microsoft.PackageDependencyResolution.targets](https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/blob/master/src/Tasks/Microsoft.NET.Build.Tasks/build/Microsoft.PackageDependencyResolution.targets). (You can create your own SDK by copying `%VSINSTALLDIR%MSBuild\Sdks\Microsoft.NET.Sdk` and removing unneeded targets)

Eventually we hope to provide a formal way to do this on top of CPS (tracked by https://github.com/dotnet/project-system/issues/2491 and https://github.com/dotnet/project-system/issues/1984).

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Announcing the NuGet 'Announcements' repo!" (#1) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
| Spec wiki| Discussion issue| 
| ------------- |:-------------| 
| _None_| https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4088|

## Announcing the **Announcements** repo!
As a step towards engaging with the community early on, we have created the **NuGet/Announcements** repo to propose new features and to get early feedback before the team starts implementing these features. This repo will be used for team announcements only. To file a bug or start a discussion, please create a new issue on [NuGet client](https://github.com/nuget/home/issues) or [NuGet server](https://github.com/nuget/NuGetGallery/issues). .

All items posted to this repo are locked, but will typically have links to separate discussion threads on one of the NuGet repos, just like this announcement can be discussed more on this issue: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4088. 
Please use these discussion threads for questions and comments about a particular announcement.

## Receiving Notifications

Subscribe to this repo to be notified about major changes, upcoming features and other noteworthy announcements in NuGet.

![subscribe](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14800916/29544263-bea081fa-869b-11e7-9c18-b576890ba049.png)

## Using the Issues list

Use the [Feature](https://github.com/nuget/Announcements/labels/Feature) and [Breaking Change](https://github.com/nuget/Announcements/labels/Breaking%20Change) labels to see what's new and changed.

New feature announcements will have one of the following labels:
* [Reviewing](https://github.com/nuget/Announcements/labels/Reviewing) - Feature being proposed and is undergoing review within the team and the community. 
* [Reviewed](https://github.com/nuget/Announcements/labels/Reviewed) - Feature has been reviewed and necessary feedback incorporated. The feature is ready to be implemented.
* [Implemented](https://github.com/nuget/Announcements/labels/Implemented) - Feature has been implemented.
